marc:datafield.marc:subfield: U.S. Army general; veteran of the War of 1812, the Seminole Wars, the Black Hawk War, and the Mexican American War.

Collection contains chiefly a photostatic copy of a report of 1838 from Gaines, concerning national defense, emphasizing the importance of railroads, and criticizing reliance on defense works and fortifications. Included is a discussion of the systems he proposed in his CANALS AND TURNPIKE ROADS (1826), and the constitutional justification for his plan. Other items are a letter regarding the jewelry and estate of his wife, Myra Clark Gaines (1857), and a letter from Gaines to George Bomford regarding a requisition for supplies (1815).

Benjamin A. Garlinger was an active public official in Hagerstown, Maryland, in the mid-19th century. Appointments included sheriff (1855), tax collector (1862-1863), and school commissioner (1872-1880).
Collection consists of business and personal letters and legal documents relating to Benjamin Garlinger, Sr. The legal documents include land deeds for Maryland.
Residents of Sullivan County, Tennessee; relatives of Edmund Pendelton Gaines and George Strother Gaines.

Letters to Gaines and his wife, Letitia, of Sullivan County, Tenn., from family and business associates, with comments on the sale of an enslaved person in 1845, on a camp meeting, and on a yellow fever epidemic in Alabama in 1854.
Postmaster of Cunningham's Store, Person County, N.C.
Cataloged from card file, originally described 1935.

Amanda Gardner was originally from Yorkville, S.C., and moved to Edneyville, N.C. and Pleasant Hill, Ala., where she married E. Gardner in the early 1840s. The Gardners eventually moved to Cahaba, Alabama. The couple had at least two children: Elizabeth "Lizzie" Gardner, who attended Presbyterian Female Collegiate Institute in Alabama but died in either 1855 or 1856; and John A. Gardner, who served under Robert Rodes in an Alabama regiment of the Confederate Army, but who died in the Battle of Seven Pines in 1862.

Collection consists of letters to Amanda E. Edney, later Amanda Gardner, from her friend Mary Serina Harris, her children, and many others. The correspondence contains comments on social life and customs in the antebellum South; discussions of "Nullifiers" in North Carolina; descriptions by Mary of Florida with references to the dangers from Indians and to the climate; letters about E. Gardner's work at the Greenville Land Office; and her daughter Elizabeth's education at Presbyterian Female Collegiate Institute, Talladega, Ala., 1854-1855. Civil War letters from her son, John A. Gardner, a Confederate soldier, describe a military skirmish, the first battle of Manassas (1st Bull Run), camp life, illness, Confederate censorship, hospitals, the election of regimental officers, wages, and conscriptions. A letter from Dr. Thomas Hunter tells of John's death in 1862. A March 1865 letter from C. W. Hayes thanks Amanda Gardner for loaning books to the Union prisoners at Fort Morgan, Mobile, Alabama.
Editor and journalist, of Hartford, Conn., and Philadelphia, Pa.

Letters to Gardner relating to his work in Boston, Mass., Richmond, Va., and Hartford, Conn., on newspapers and periodicals including the Boston Quarterly Review, Brother Jonathan, Democratic Review, States Rights Republican (Richmond), The Sunbeam (Hartford), and Union and Messenger. Topics include Democratic politics, social democracy, and political reforms. Correspondents include Theophilus Fisk, who wrote from Portsmouth, Va., inviting Gardner to be editor of a weekly paper in Richmond that would advocate for a new state constitution, suffrage, public education, and labor rights.
Officer in the U.S. Marine Corps, based in Washington, D.C.; active mid-19th century.

Collection consists of Garland's promotion letters from the U.S. Marine Corps, signed by the secretaries of the Navy: James C. Dobbin, John Y. Mason, Sr., and Gideon Welles; also includes Garland's certificate of membership for the U.S. Naval Lyceum.
Darius Gandy (Darlington, S.C.) was a planter and slaveholder; his daughter, Harriet, attended the Salem Female Academy in Salem, N.C.

Collection consists of fragmentary family correspondence Darius, Harriet, and Daniel Gandy. Collection includes an account sheet showing the expenses of Harriet Gandy at the Salem Female Academy, Salem, N.C., 1862; a printed circular (1863) enumerating regulations for the handling and distribution of Confederate Army supplies in Georgia; and a letter (1865) concerning details of executing the law to impress slaves for labor on Confederate fortifications.

Diary (44 pp.) chiefly describing Gardner's daily routines and life in Nantucket during the mid-19th century. She describes arrivals of whaling ships, health of people in community, and pastimes. Details enthusiastic welcome Lucy Stone received when she came to Nantucket to lecture about women's rights and abolition.
Robert S. Garnett letter to S. Lansing, Jr.,
Army officer and commandant of cadets, 1852-1854, at the United States Military Academy, West Point; Confederate brigadier general who was killed in 1861 at the Battle of Carrick's Ford.
Letter from Garnett to Lansing concerning an unserviceable mess kit.
William A. Gallup account and commonplace book,

Collection comprises an account and commonplace book maintained by Gallup between 1857 and 1859. Gallup began using the item as an account book for "expenses while in the employ of Henry Bill, Norwich, Conn." during a trip to Chicago from 7 Apr 1857 to 20 Jan 1858 (p. 3-6). Expenses noted included fares for travel, board, washing, omnibuses, etc. He also maintained records of his personal account with Bill (p. 26-27) which he marked as settled on 27 Jan 1857. Despite these accounts, the nature of his employment is unclear. Gallup also used the item as a commonplace book, where he recorded such information as his weight, state and road taxes, the amounts of his shares held in whaling and other ventures (p. 39), lists of sundry expenses (p. 42-43), instructions for calculating weights and measures, as well as his church attendance (Presbyterian, Methodist, and Baptist), notes from a lecture on anatomy and physiology by Dr. Weiting at Metropolitan Hall in Chicago (19 Apr 1857), and lists of letters written. The final entry in the piece is noted on the inside back cover, for cash in funds, [bills?], and change, on 2 Jan 1859.
John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

Civil War letters to Caroline Gardner from friends and cousins. Primary correspondents are Thomas J. Gardner, 2nd Regiment, North Carolina Cavalry, and Marshall Moffitt. Topics include camp life, military skirmishes, prisoners from First Manassas arriving in Tarboro, a train accident, and disappointment over a speech by Governor Vance, 1864. Also included are papers of the Kivett family of Missouri, who appear to have been friends of Caroline Gardner. These containing descriptions of Texas County, Mo., as well as some Civil War correspondence from Jacob Kivett.
Peter Cordes Gaillard letter to H. M. Haig,
Charleston, S.C. resident; physician and editor of the Charleston Medical Journal.
Item is a letter to Dr. H. M. Haig in Paris, France, concerning business matters, rental of a house owned by Haig in Charleston, and a monument to be erected in memory of John C. Calhoun.
Confederate soldier and physician from Birmingham and Livingston, Alabama.

Collection consists of two letters and an address by James Garber. The first letter concerns the purchase of land by a member of the Garber family; the second was written by Garber while he was a Confederate soldier, about the treatment of his horses while he was absent from the regiment. The address, "The Doctor and His Office," was delivered by Garber to the Birmingham Baptist Hospital. It is a philosophical treatment of the role and responsibilities of physicians to society.

Collection consists of Civil War-era letters to the Gaffney family of Columbia, S.C., from friends and relatives. A letter (1862) written by P. Lemmons of the 12th South Carolina infantry (Gregg's Brigade) while he was at Camp Arsenal Green in Charleston, S.C., describes the stealing of a steamship, THE PLANTER, by a party of African Americans. Several letters were written by William W. Gaffney to his parents during the Civil War: one (1862 May 20) from Camp Jackson in Spottsylvania, Va., These describe the events of battles in Virginia and Pennsylvania. Two items deal with financial matters at Furman University.
Member of Company E, 46th Regiment, Massachusetts Volunteers.
Collection contains two letters from Gaines while stationed near New Bern, N.C. during the winter of 1862. He complains that the weather is disagreeable, the food is bad, and that army life is dull.
New Bern (Craven Co.), N.C., shipping agent.

Personal and business letters and shipping invoices addressed to Gardner. Letters mention commodity prices in North Carolina. Invoices list merchandise shipped from New York City to New Bern on American ships: Agile, J. W. Haig, H. Hill, Louisa Moore, and H. H. Thompson.

Collection contains two letters of recommendation by Garfield for office seekers; an 1881 invitation to Garfield's inaugural ball; a facsimile of an 1880 letter from Garfield to Marshall Jewel, chairman of the Republican National Committee, denouncing as a forgery the Morey letter concerning Chinese immigration; an 1882 announcement of a memorial service in Garfield's honor; a certificate issued to J. A. Brookshier, a contributing member of the Garfield National Masonic Memorial Association of Washington, D.C.; and typescripts of two speeches, approximately 1899 and 1906, delivered by an unknown alumnus of Hiram College and containing reminiscences of classmate James A. Garfield.
Cataloged from Guide and accession records.
Collection consists of personal and family letters directed to Miss Ella Gaither from a cousin, friend, and suitor.
During the Civil War, Charles Gallagher served as purveyor to General Benjamin F. Butler and advisor to L.C. Baker in tracing the assassin of Abraham Lincoln.

Collection contains Gallagher's papers, including a letter of application for appointment as special agent in the Internal Revenue Service, 1885, discussing his Civil War service with Butler and Baker; also contains statements, Congressional bills, and other papers relating to Gallagher's claims for relief for the loss of his schooner NIMROD, destroyed by Confederates on Dec. 5, 1864.
Collection consists of love letters between Jack Garnet and his girlfriend, Edith R. (unknown last name).
